Most of us know, or think we know, what it‚Äôs like to be homeless or on the brink of losing a home. On the flip side, it‚Äôs a sweet dream to imagine living out of a small trailer for a short vacation down at the lake. But this fictionalized bit completely believable story melds those two visions by shining a light on those vagabonds permanently living on wheels, with no fixed address. Along the way, opens up whole worlds: of people with pride and identity but forced to be continually on the move when the monthly or semi yearly rental agreement ends: always on the edge, looking for something better, without any real prospects on the horizon. This is a feast or famine existence, where a lucky few get short-term employment at best and seemingly live without plans, from hand to mouth. At worst there is the prospect of disease and old age hitting with no support systems built into a trailer park or roadside stop. At best, there are impromptu communities and warm sharing of resources‚Äîbut these are fragile networks, like feathers in the wind. The vagabonds move on and on, sometimes meeting again randomly‚Äîor not at all. This was a highly original work in the style of a documentary built on a simple empathetic character trying to build a life on shaky ground..the small world of a camper, clothes in one corner and portapotty in another. There‚Äôs little energy left for looking back about mistakes made. There‚Äôs only the decision about how to do the laundry, and where to find groceries this week. With a turn of bad luck, almost any of us could be in her shoes. This chance to have our eyes opened to the possibility is the gift that this movie offers.

This movie is based on the eponymous book by Jessica Bruder, which was published in 2017, with the subtitle ‚ÄúSurviving America in the 21st Century.‚Äù I read and reviewed the book on Amazon in June 2019. It provided an insight into one of the subcultures of American life: people who choose, or more often are forced by economic necessity, to move from place to place within our borders. Within the last couple of months, I watched and reviewed Werner Herzog‚Äôs tribute to Bruce Chatwin, entitled ‚ÄúNomad ‚Äì In the Footsteps of Bruce Chatwin.‚Äù A core theme of the movie was about Chatwin‚Äôs fascination with people who move from place to place. Thus, when I saw that Chloe Zhao had directed a movie based on Bruder‚Äôs book, and particularly because it stars Frances McDormand, whose acting ability I have admired since seeing her play the sheriff in ‚ÄúFargo,‚Äù I knew this was a must-see film, despite Amazon‚Äôs heaviest price tag for a movie: 6 bucks. McDormand plays Fern, who had led a reasonably comfortable life in the company town that US Gypsum had constructed at Empire, which is in northwestern Nevada (its current population in 65). Fern‚Äôs husband died after a long illness and US Gypsum shut its plant for making sheetrock, after 88 years of operation, in 2011. Fern is suddenly without a home and has to hit the road, with limited resources and only her van to live in, thereby entering the nomadic subculture. The movie provides the visual images that the book could not, highlighted by McDormand‚Äôs stoic face as she deals with adversity, or even ‚Äúa good day.‚Äù Fern and other nomads work at Amazon warehouses, temporarily, fulfilling the need for seasonal labor during the winter holiday season. Another big employer are the various campgrounds that need on-site hosts, during the summer season. There is also flipping hamburgers at Wall Drugs (of the many, many billboards) in South Dakota, and the beet harvest in Nebraska. All a slice of economic and social life in the fly-over zone. Zhao cinematography created some great images. Quartzsite Arizona is just off I-10, near the California line. The modern-day Bedouin gather there in the winter, after release from Amazon‚Äôs seasonal demands. They sit around the campfire, with a ‚Äúguru‚Äù of sorts, who helps them adjust to their new nomadic lives with positive advice. He has coined an aphorism: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt say goodbye, just say I‚Äôll see you down the road.‚Äù The movie incorporates numerous real-life nomads, using their real names. But I had a few more problems with the movie than even the book. Sitting around the campfire, briefly identifying themselves, going around the circle, Zhao decides to include one of the hoariest of clich√©s: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a Vietnam Veteran and I suffer from PTSD.‚Äù Yes, there is an extremely slender portion of the population that fit that description, but for unknown reasons Zhao excludes how the vast majority of people arrived at that campfire, as described by Bruder: ‚Äú‚Ä¶due to the economic circumstance of the Americans, many of whom had ‚Äòplayed by all the rules.‚Äô Many were on the road because they had ‚Äòdrunk the Kool-Aid‚Äô of always rising housing prices, and in 2008-09, watched the government bail out the bankers, who had caused the problem, but not the homeowners. Many others were there due to medical bills they could not pay and the subsequent bankruptcy. Others due to downsizing and ageism. Divorces, of course. More than half the American nomads are woman, in the 50‚Äôs and beyond.‚Äù Zhao also decided to completely shear from the movie the violence that nomads must face. In the movie they mention Linda May building her ‚Äúearthship‚Äù in the Arizona desert that will be there for her grandchildren but omits what Bruder said in the book about her neighbor carrying an AR-15 because of all the drug runners. Oh well, I did like the images, even though it seemed to get stuck on sunrises and sunsets, and I do like the music of Ludovico Einaudi. 4-stars.

I agree with the reviewer who called it a story of resilience. The protagonist is in a very "non-Hollywood" age/sex/socioeconomic/ geographic demographic, yet her housing/job predicament is not uncommon, and is in fact a sociohistorical phenomenon that is worth a look, so this is an unusual and *more-than-refreshing choice* (!!) for a character study. People with ADD will find Nomadland boring. They can move on and watch cartoons or Bruce Willis movies or T&A or whatever. They won't find what they're looking for here. It is indeed very quiet and slow-moving, and nothing is spelled out for you. The landscapes are bleak, inspiring, and beautiful. The story tells itself without shoving anything in anyone's face or treating the viewer as stupid. I wouldn't call it a "liberal movie". Millions of proud, independent people live on the edge in a highly developed nation, and this is thought-provoking, whatever your political stripe. I looked for other movies similar to it after watching it, because of the quality and unusualness of it, but haven't found a single one yet even similar to it! Would like to see more cinematographic work of this level, and fewer "grand-scale, plastic, special fx" type things and Pixar crapola. It doesn't have a pat or fairytale ending, and what impresses is the spirit of these lower-income displaced people and their sense of community, their love of freedom. The movie doesn't look down on these people, or preach at the viewer. They just are what they are. If you like Studs T and show-don't-tell realism, you will like this award-winning oeuvre.

This film is more of a documentary than a drama. There is really no need to go into spoilers, because the movie really isn't about our protagonist, so much as shinning a light on the American Gypsy. From the start, we get a down on her luck woman, who slowly adopts the nomadic lifestyle to a point she cannot envision any other life. We get only tidbits of her story, peppered here and there in the dialogue, leaving us almost entirely in the present, which leaves the viewer with very little reason to sympathize with are main character as she has no visible character arc to make her more or less interesting. On her journey, she meets a colorful cast of other gypsies and is confronted by family and friends whom misunderstand her life style. That's it, roll credits. I won't deny, its a beautifully constructed film that expertly portrays the the spiral that leads to a nomadic lifestyle. What it lacks is substance that would make the movie interesting. There is no climax, there is no steady progression, or even any real character progression. What you get in the first 10 minutes of the movie, is pretty much what you get the whole movie. There is no central theme, or arc. The movie just meanders from event to event with only the flimsiest of connections. Every Act is essentially the same as the last one. As a 3-act film, its boring. However, taken as a fictional documentary, it provides an intricate insight into a class of people most Americans are completely oblivious to and what many Europeans are very familiar with. Good Movie, that is expertly directed and well acted, but insanely dull if your looking for entertainment.

There are few things in life that instill sheer terror and anxiety like living in the squalor of poverty. War is one. Until the onset of mass incarceration and big data, virtually all Americans had been privileged for over a hundred years not to have to experience bondage or enslavement as another. But in 2021 it doesn‚Äôt matter so much whether you want Google, Facebook or Amazon. They all want you. and pretty much aren‚Äôt taking ‚Äúno‚Äù for an answer. One way to seemingly evade the slow creep of digital stalking into our lives might seem the isolation and loneliness omnipresent in Chloe Zhao‚Äôs Nomadland. In one way it presents the answer to those who feel their privacy and sense of self eroded over the past twenty years. In another, such a lifestyle is a very poor substitute indeed, and a price most can‚Äôt afford. For starters, people of a certain age do tend live like McDormand. Not so much in vans or on the road. But in the ways we have been wronged in life, and the ways we have wronged others, forgiveness isn‚Äôt so much a practice but a coping mechanism that enables us to maintain useful relationships, friendships and even contact with less than fortunate family and extended family. Nomadland only briefly touches on and then quickly glosses over themes of death, substance abuse, terminal illness and severe mental illness that cannot always be escaped by sleeping in the back of our minivans for a few weeks or months. In fact, often, those are part of the forces and poorer personal choices that make living harder and worse, for those already experiencing hardship. Nomadland thankfully stays true to these realities of ‚Äústreet living‚Äù even while glossing over much of the grittier subject matter. McDormand provides an amiable enough character who does not ‚Äòdeserve‚Äô to be subjugated to her van-dwelling depression, perhaps any more than the average van-dweller deserves an Oscar just for living in a van. Such are the strange times that we find ourselves in, when those who cannot even afford a subscription service to see their lives played out in the celluloid, find themselves at least represented by talented story-tellers, if not robbed and misappropriated of the real pain, suffering and hardship of their all too real personal experiences.

review_text: This is a wonderful movie, but a quiet one that builds subtly. It also treads ground that is difficult and can be dark. It does wind up with a coherent ending, so doesn't just leave you hanging, but it might not be apparent at first -- or appealing, as the lead character, Fern, makes some out of the ordinary life choices that might make some people feel uncomfortable. In America, at least, we are not much trained to approve of people who make lifestyle choices far different from our own ... unless perhaps they strike it rich in the process. I hope I can help make the movie easier to swallow for those who want to feel their way through it as well as those who don't, or are left unsure. Fern loses her husband and becomes mentally and emotionally paralyzed in the process. Still practical, she does what she can with her limited resources and builds out a van -- that is, equips it in a modest way for living in. No showers or anything glorious like that; she's not a plumber or radiating money. Then she hits the road. There she meets other people who have come to an unusual lifestyle, some by choice, many by necessity. She works at a few season jobs, encounters a possible future mate, learns to live differently, and visits her sister. The latter is a situation I would describe as both caring and a bit overbearing as only family can be. The implication throughout this movie, and throughout our society really, is that everything Fern is doing is wrong and should be changed. That should she feel differently, she is wrong and traveling down a dangerous road that could not lead to either security or happiness and that path is therefore of very little value at best ... but more comparable to being reeled in to one's doom. Everyone else knows what's best for Fern before she's even sure what she herself wants. The movie is not explicit with its value judgments regarding Fern or how she thinks and feels. It merely lets Fern live and discover for herself. There will be no "right answer" for you or I or Fern in this movie. The movie is essentially about hard freedoms and obligations and their trade-offs. I think most of us were raised to find Fern's trials and tribulations to be barely contained nightmare. Fern and everyone she has known for most of her life were likely raised to think exactly the same. What the movie is about is not Fern being right or wrong, but becoming truly open to her choices and what they are all about, what it is to be her and and the prices she will pay for that no matter what she does. You will find people saying Fern is wrong in many ways, and so finding the movie irredeemably dark and pointless because, after all, we DO know best. That will even anger some people and make them dismiss it. I'd suggest seeing it, watching it with an open mind, and keeping in mind that other people's choices are not our own and do not have to be. Not even to be good. For them at least. Or maybe not. But the freedom to decide is something to embrace, too. So is the freedom to see possibilities creatively. You can exercise your own freedom to see possibilities creatively by watching the movie with an open and sympathetic eye.
review_header: Love, freedom and their tough decisions

‚ÄúNomadland‚Äù Distributed by Searchlight Pictures, 108 Minutes, Rated R, Released February 09, 2021: Fiction and reality are artfully crafted together in ‚ÄúNomadland,‚Äù the new motion picture from filmmaker Chloe Zhao and Searchlight Pictures that‚Äôs generating a lot of talk about Academy Award nominations. As with her previous films, Zhao casts actors and non-actors together in a mostly real situation to produce a timely and often moving hybrid of life and art. Based on--or rather inspired by--journalist Jessica Bruder‚Äôs 2017 nonfiction social studies examination ‚ÄúNomadland: Surviving America in the Twenty-First Century,‚Äù in Zhao‚Äôs picture a sixty-something widow loses her job with the 2011 closure of the local US Gypsum plant in Empire, Nevada. The manufacturing complex is a casualty of the Great Recession of 2008, a business failure which effectively eliminates an entire US Zip Code. With few resources and no close family since the recent death of her husband, the newly-unemployed widow sells most of her belongings, buys a secondhand minibus, and takes to the road, traveling through the western United States searching for temporary or seasonal jobs to sustain her. During her odyssey, she discovers an entire population of people like herself--a demographic of modern nomads called ‚Äùcampers,‚Äù displaced by the economy, traveling from state to state in search of work, living nowhere...and everywhere. Filmmaker Chloe Zhao, best known for her 2018 serio-documentary western ‚ÄúThe Rider,‚Äù finds in Bruder‚Äôs 2017 study another carefully-shaded human drama, a dynamic of modern American society with echoes of the Dust Bowl and Great Depression in the 1930s: Strong and independent spirits searching for a place to sustain themselves on the American prairies. In her source book, Jessica Bruder describes the people as ‚Äúa wandering tribe‚Äù investing in ‚Äúwheel estate (and) driving away from the impossible choices which face what used to be called the middle class.‚Äù As with her previous films, Zhao with ‚ÄúNomadland‚Äù is careful to avoid condescending to her subject, or patronizing her characters. While the failing economy might‚Äôve been the catalyst for the odyssey and migration of some of the people in ‚ÄúNomadland,‚Äù for others the road has become a way of life. For those, the sound of the highway has become as comforting as the sound of the ocean surf or the rustling of leaves on a summer evening. With the exception of its two central roles, the rest of Zhao‚Äôs cast is made up of non-actors, actual campers living in the style of the characters they portray onscreen. In the role of the displaced widow, actress Frances McDormand with her weathered and careworn face and weary, intelligent eyes can wring more emotion from silence than other actors can convey with a page of dialogue. Rather than a movie star, McDormand seems like one of us. And in ‚ÄúNomadland‚Äù her character‚Äôs circumstances might‚Äôve changed, but her dignity is intact. Discovered by the child of a former neighbor relaxing in a Walmart lawn chair at Christmastime, she‚Äôs asked whether the rumors are true that she‚Äôs homeless. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù McDormand reassures her young friend, ‚ÄùI‚Äôm houseless--not the same thing.‚Äù In its pervasive sense of an elemental nobility among its characters, ‚ÄúNomadland'' bears favorable comparisons with John Ford‚Äôs classic 1940 film ‚ÄúThe Grapes of Wrath‚Äù...and the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel on which it was based. In fact, the highest accolade for ‚ÄúNomadland‚Äù might be that it helps to define America at the beginning of the 21st century. It‚Äôs a movie John Steinbeck would‚Äôve been proud of. Filming of ‚ÄúNomadland‚Äù took place over four months during the autumn of 2018 with director Zhao and cast members McDormand and David Strathairn living in actual campgrounds on locations along the way in Arizona, Nevada, Nebraska, South Dakota, and California. America‚Äôs magnificent western vistas are beautifully photographed for the picture by cinematographer Joshua James Richards--in many first-run cities, the film is being presented in the IMAX format. Author Jessica Bruder‚Äôs source material was also adapted into a 2017 documentary short subject by filmmaker Brett Story entitled ‚ÄúCamperForce.‚Äù Vastly different in tone than the soulful ‚ÄúNomadland,‚Äù ‚ÄúCamperForce,‚Äù is easily available for viewing on YouTube. ‚ÄúNomadland‚Äù is rated R for nudity, and some adult themes.

review_text: Anyone who's been around for more than 3 decades should understand that this is a cliche' social commentary. Basic story template: Person faces disappointment after their failed American dream. Having become disillusioned and facing adversity they "drop out" and embrace self-pity as a lifestyle choice. They view everything though a foggy, dark gray lens. Briefly they return to reality (in this case to borrow money from relatives) only to use the opportunity to insult those that choose a more mainstream (and actually happier) existence. Then, possibly because they are addicted to self-pity, they return to the gray netherworld of their own making. This is a trope of novels and young "film-makers" that gets reproduced every few years. Every new batch of creators and critics seems to think they are the first to take a cynical view of life (especially middle-class life), so we see this gray goop reemerge periodically. Even the cinematography is cliche'. Yes, yes, a really expensive 4K camera, super expensive lenses and hundreds of hours of digital editing will produce amazing, affecting images. Big deal. I can do that with my iPhone. Anyone can lease professional grade camera equipment. The point is that the cinematic metaphors used in this are basic film school stock. In the end this is just a story of a self-righteous person who sees misery and self-pity as a rewarding life path. Another title for this film could be "Sad Sack". Here's the ironic part: The main character is shown working at Amazon and there are overtones of the dehumanizing exploitation of such employment. I laughed at the irony of my paying Amazon $3.99 to watch this drivel. Turns out I was the one who was exploited and now disillusioned! Can I have my money back? I really wanted to enjoy this but it's really weak and somewhat predictable.

review_text: I really don't care for the first part of Chloe Zhao's _Nomadland_. Most supporting characters are played by non-professionals. The problem there is that Zhao, like so many directors who use non-professional actors, feels obliged to present the views of these nomadic workers with excessive respect and intimacy, like every word is a priceless pearl of wisdom -- even when one of them has a Confederate flag tattoo on his arm (if memory serves)! The camera seems stuck to them head-on. It is hard not to make a comparison with the itinerant workers in _Days of Heaven_, which Terrence Malick depicts at a glancing angle, so the camera bounces off, keeping a phyiscal and emotional distance Unlike _Days_, there is no background music, no sense of awe, and _Nomadland_ seems an exercise in miserabilism. After the 35 minute mark, suddenly it is a completely different film. A soulful piano score permeates the second half (music is use too excessively and repetitively, in fact), David Strathairn shows up as a cook in a diner to give the story an anchor, and McDormand's character gets to stay with his family, her own family, and even to enjoy herself outdoors. There is even some cohesion to the visual motifs; a hollow rock, its lightness and airiness, is made to contrast with the back-breaking rock-hard potatoes she signs up to pack. There is also a philosophical touch about the origin of life in a dinosaur theme park. None of this is very original of course; the dinosaur extinction piece suffers from comparison with Romain Laguna's _Meteorites_, where it is the major leitmotif, and the camera work and art-house mannerism are nothing you haven't seen before. _Nomadland_ does not have the deeply personal, revelatory feel of, say, A.J. Edwards' work, never mind fellow female Marvel excursion helmer Cate Shortland's. Still, the second half by itself makes for an above average art film. Why create a film that is so uneven though? The most unusual thing about _Nomadland_ is the age of its female protagonist (McDormand is in her late 60s). In a way this celebration of a salt-of-the-earth type reminds me of David Lynch's _The Straight Story_, which generated its share of plaudits when it came out. And then ... nothing. I honestly haven't heard anyone mention this film in at least 15 years, despite Lynch's auteur status. _Nomadland_ has the distinct feel of a film given obligatory hype, but is doomed to be forgotten soon afterwards.
review_header: Uneven; the second half is a decent art-house offering

I don‚Äôt often write reviews but this film touched me on such a deep level I was moved to write. It‚Äôs more a character study than plot, and mixes quiet stories both of real people and and the composite main character who seamlessly fits in with the others. As someone now around the age of Fern in this film, who during the past COVID year has realized both the incredible lack of safety nets available in this country during times of recession or serious illness (and being in the first generation facing elder years without pensions or adequate healthcare), at a time of life where personal losses and job discrimination steadily increase across socioeconomic classes, I was moved to see so much resilience and beauty in the very difficult lifestyle choices they made. The real stories added a lot. I have a friend who did live this van life for a decade before serious health issues set in and I know both how hard the life is and yet how connected they felt both to the land and fellow travelers. The travelers are mostly apolitical which I also really appreciated. No soapbox - just quietly understated journey. In the midst of personal loss this film filled me with hope and appreciation of the resilience and creativity we have to still make choices, and the ways even seemingly disconnected people still find connection and beauty in life.

This movie is a detailed portrait of a particular person and personality that can't settle down. Francis McDormand turns in another incredible acting job, much of which doesn't involve speaking. Her character keeps moving from job to job, place to place, making friends and facing struggles along the way. She just barely gets by as her body ages, living out of her car and working unforgiving jobs as the seasonal work calls for the next migration. I can't say I know why some people are like this, but I have known people who are like that, so it's real. Perhaps they can't or don't want to conform their conduct as necessary to live in long stable situations -- so its a life style based on a concept of personal freedom. Maybe each person has their own reasons. The movie is very "small" and detailed, and I would imagine to a typical movie audience, it could seem boring. But let yourself be drawn into it and open yourself to understanding the whys and wherefores of this lifestyle, and it is very powerful and raises some big questions about how most of us live our lives. It's interesting to see the kindness that folks in this "community" show to each other, and how little they can live with in terms of material possessions. Some of the actors are real people from the migrant/nomadic living community recruited for the movie. It added further power to the movie. It deserved the Oscars it won -- the big ones: best movie, best director, best actress.

After stowing away her material possessions and hitting the highway, a widowed van-dweller roams the seasonal workplaces and temporary sanctuaries of the transient life. It's a lonesome road, one of fleeting connections and uncertain destinations; a solitary existence that's half choice and half necessity. I‚Äôve noticed a certain sense of daydreamy romanticism floating around this sort of lifestyle recently, the glamorized prospect of working from a cel signal with the great outdoors as a backdrop, but Nomadland strips away much of that veneer in showing the other side of the coin. There's promise in such freedom, but also great risk, and not every van lifer is cut out for the harsh realities of such a compartmentalized existence. Frances McDormand drew a best actress Oscar for her portrayal of Fern, the wandering protagonist whose compassion leads her to make deep connections with similar spirits, but whose withdrawn emotional restlessness forces those relationships to remain decidedly brief. She's wonderful, as expected, with an expressive authenticity that can make the film feel more like a documentary than a staged drama. Evidently, moviegoers weren't the only ones taken by that convincing act: without a firm script, much of the film's dialogue is delivered by true nomads who happened into the indie-scale production and, taking McDormand for one of their own, opened up to her. That knowledge can cause the film to teeter a bit too close to exploitation, but it also lends extra credibility and sentimental power to the viewing experience. Gloomy but stirring, with a potent contemporary subject, a number of rich supporting characters (if they're actually characters at all), a beautiful photographic sense and a smooth narrative flow. It‚Äôs a meaningful picture, if not an uplifting one.

Warning: Spoilers Rating: 2.5 out of 5.0 I saw director Chloe Zhao's first two films at Spirit Award screenings in 2015 and 2017 and that time complained that they were both lugubrious with paltry plotting. I am sad to report that despite displaying her consistent technical prowess as a director, Zhao still is unable to come up with a clever story that hits all the marks for a successful three act screenplay. Based on a non-fiction book of the same name by Jessica Bruder, Zhao taped interviews with various "Nomads" (self-described as "houseless" as opposed to "homeless" by the film's protagonist, Fern, played by Frances McDormand), and incorporated some of their stories into the film. Some of the actual non-actor Nomads Zhao interviewed are cast in the film and perhaps provide the most colorful moments as we follow the protagonist's journey. The plot focuses on Fern, who after losing her job as a result of the 2008 economic downturn (the gypsum plant she worked at closes) decides to put most of her possessions in storage and go on the road, living out of a run-down camper. It's noted that the town where she's from-Empire, Nevada-faces a mass exodus of its inhabitants, eventually leading to the elimination of the town's zip code from the postal service directory. To add insult to injury, shortly before she goes on the road, Fern's husband passes away, leaving her at first bewildered, only to take solace later on by embracing (by what some may call) "rugged individualism." We learn that because the Nomads are unable to subsist on their social security checks alone, they're forced to take seasonal employment to support themselves. Thus we follow Fern first as she takes a job at an Amazon Fulfillment Center and later other jobs including a camp host at the Cedar Pass Campground in Badlands National Park, a restaurant job in South Dakota and later at a sugar beet processing plant. As we keep following Fern, we're introduced to various real-life characters such as Bob Wells, a sort of self-help guru for the Nomad community, who runs a desert rendezvous in Arizona. Wells proves to be an interesting father figure to the community but has little to do with the plot involving Fern, possibly with the exception of a heartfelt conversation they have together at film's end in which he reveals the pain he experienced following his adult son's suicide. Less successful in terms of developing Fern's story, is a subplot involving another nomad, Swankie, who's facing a cancer diagnosis and decides not to spend her last days in a hospital and instead to go on one last vacation (it should be noted that Swankie's cancer is a standard fictional construct and Zhao uses it to manipulate our emotions-a completely unnecessary strategy given the rich backstories of the various real-life nomads). The Nomadland plot basically revolves around whether Fern decides to continue on the road or not. There's the friendship with Dave (David Strathairn) who eventually opts to stay with his son and daughter-in-law who have a new baby. Toward the end of the film Fern visits Dave at the son's house but declines to accept his invitation to live there in a guest house. Perhaps the crisis of the second Act is when Fern's camper breaks down and she's forced to take a bus to California to borrow money for repairs from her sister. All's well that ends well when the sister obligingly gives her the needed funds. The scene with the sister is indicative of Zhao's persistent desire to idealize her protagonist's situation-the worst the sister can say to Fern is that she was always "eccentric"-nonetheless, she praises her, again for the previously alluded to "rugged individualism." In a sense, Fern is the updated version of the "noble savage." In the days when Native Americans were castigated as savages, there was (if I may utilize a Freudian term here), a reaction formation in which certain writers in the 19th century went to the opposite extreme and depicted them as uncorrupted outsiders, emphasizing an innate, essential goodness. The same could be said for certain individuals today of a more liberal, progressive bent who seek to help the "homeless" in all ways possible, ignoring other aspects of their self-destructive behavior and threat they may present to the social order. Indeed we only see Fern get angry once (when Dave breaks some of her dishes by accident) and the reality of community opposition to the nomad lifestyle is only hinted at occasionally. When Fern clings to her camper and refuses to sell it because she's constructed it as a special "home away from home," it becomes painfully obvious that her possessiveness is akin to a tried and true hoarder which many of us are familiar with from a fairly well known cable TV program. Indeed the unhealthy interior of the camper is only hinted at also occasionally (Fern complains about ants in the van as well as having to relieve herself once into a bucket after experiencing a bad reaction to something she eats). Ultimately Zhao leans a little too much toward idealizing her protagonist and unfortunately McDormand can do little with a script that emphasizes a monochromatic personality. Fern is simply bland and seems to relish in avoiding conflict. And that's what Nomadland perhaps lacks the most: conflict! In the end, Zhao has her heroine Fern returning to the road, afraid to suggest that maybe everything is not peachy keen in Nomadland. Despite some beautiful cinematography and use of music, Zhao appears content to remain in her indie niche, lucky to win an Oscar for Best Picture but probably the last time that will occur.
review_header: Underdeveloped plot (once again) highlights indie director's idealized portrait of nomadic lifestyle

Whenever I see a film, I ask myself a few questions: Did the movie make a strong or lasting impression on me? Did I learn anything new from it that I had not known before? Did any of the characters resonate with me with his/her situation being particularly unique and insightful? On all these fronts the movie came up short. I quickly forgot about the movie as soon as I finished it. I tried to keep asking what was the point of the film. Is it that even though we try to escape the hardships and trappings of society, we cannot escape them, as the past is constantly haunting us? Or is it that we all are vulnerable to the system (reliance on Amazon etc) even though we try to free ourselves from it? Even if either one was the theme of the film, the exploration of it was not done in any penetrating manner. Technically also I found the film to be somewhat disjointed. I think the director could have done a much better job in turning this into a documentary instead of creating a feature film. I was also surprised that Frances McDormand won an Oscar for her role in the movie. Actually there's not much to act in her role. It was a far cry from her performance in Fargo which was truly outstanding. All in all, I had been looking for a more compelling, powerful or nuanced film given all the hype about it. Given that expectation, the movie was a let down.

Aside from the glamour of the instagram vanlife there is a population of modern nomads that find themselves on the road. Some for adventure, companionship, others for the purpose of sole survival. You will be taken out of the comfort of your couch, to go on a road trip with the protagonist an aging woman that lost her home and previous life through no fault of her own. This movie is well shot and shows a realistic side of our society that seems to fail a growing number of people. The protagonists share their life with you in a part road movie, part documentary. It showcases some realistic live stories and provides a social commentary on consumerism and the disconnect of social norms to the need of many. The growing movement of nomad living that has become a chosen lifestyle for many and the Guru of Cheap RV living Bob Wells is shown in the movie, talking about his life and the life of his friends and fellow comrades. This movie is well done, worth seeing and gives a great insight into the American life outside of desperate housewife drama and celebrity fashion news. This is a portrait of our soul as a nation, the change of landscape in this vast large country, and the diverse ways in which people from all walks of life make a living. Not all fit the norm, for some its a needed escape from the rat race, for others its a freedom of self expression. Some are seeking healing in nature. All have a reason to call the open road home. It is one of the most important movies to watch. It is humble, without moral overtone and shows us a view that we might have missed otherwise. Beautifully done, worth every second of your time. No special effects, no car chases, no sex, no violence - just great storytelling from a compelling vantage point.
